title: Before 18 October 2016, will there be a confrontation involving Iran's and another country's national military forces that produces at least one fatality in the Persian Gulf, the Strait of Hormuz, or the Gulf of Oman?
preds:

The official said it was unclear what may have motivated the attacks and speculated that there may be factions within the group who have different agendas." McLeary (2016) states that: Iran says it has dispatched two warships to the Gulf of Aden to ply the same waters as several U.S. Navy vessels are already operating there, one of which launched several Tomahawk missiles at Tehran-backed Houthi radar installations early Thursday morning.
According to the Iranian Tasnim news site, which has links to the Iranian Revolutionary Guards Corps, the frigate Alvand and logistics ship Bushehr are heading to the Yemeni coast “to protect the country’s trade vessels against piracy.” But the site also notes that “the presence of the Iranian fleet in the Gulf of Aden coincides with the US decision to directly get involved in a Saudi-led war against Yemen.” Piracy has all but disappeared in the area, and the Iranian ships are scheduled to then sail south down Africa’s east 
The Iranian warship heading to the Gulf of Aden — the 45 year-old Alvand, which carries anti-ship missiles, a Mark 8 gun as well as various machine guns — already has a checkered history with the U.S. Navy. In July 2015, the ship trained its guns on a U.S. Navy helicopter and an allied supply ship operating with the USS Farragut in the waterway, but the incident was contained before any violence broke out.
The news of the deployment comes hours after the USS Nitze launched several Tomahawk missiles at three radar sites in a Houthi rebel-controlled part of Yemen, sites the U.S. believes took part in the three separate missile attacks on U.S. Navy ships operating off the Yemeni coast this week.
Yemen’s Saba news agency, which acts as a mouthpiece for the Houthi-led government, charged Thursday that “U.S. allegations” of its ships being targeted were made to create “false justifications to pave the way for Saudi-led coalition to escalate their aggression” against Yemen “and to cover for crimes continually committed” by the coalition fighting to oust the Houthis from power (para. 1-5). McLeary, P. (2016). Iran Sends Ships to Yemeni Coast in Wake of U.S. Strikes. Foreign Policy. Retrieved from
http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/10/13/iran-sends-ships-to-yemeni-coast-in-wake-of-u-s-strikes/

CBS News, October 13, 'Official: Yemen rebels fire 2 missiles at Navy ship, U.S. responds with strikes': http://www.cbsnews.com/news/official-yemen-rebels-fire-2-missiles-at-navy-ship-us-responds-with-strikes/
Clips from article:
"The missiles fired on Sunday were variants of the so-called Silkworm missile, and both also fell harmlessly into the water. The Silkworm is a type of coastal defense cruise missile that Iran has been known to use, and the Iran has backed the Shiite Houthi rebels."
Comments: Houthis deny attacks. Questions have arisen about the rebels ability to deploy and operate sophisticated weapon systems (missiles/radar); hints of Iranian control at times of recent incidents. Precedent in Ukraine, with the downing of MH17 by a Buk system allegedly manned by Russian military personnel. High probability that USS Nitze counter-strike on radar sites resulted in kills. Iranian hand may not be realized till after expiration of this IFP.

An American destroyer fired three cruise missiles at Yemen, picking out radar installations in territory controlled by Houthi rebels with ties to Iran. The bombardment was intended as retaliation for a missile launched at the USS Mason just hours earlier—the second such incident in four days. America is supporting Saudi-led forces battling the Houthis; it had not yet attacked the rebels directly

Fox News, October 3, 'US warships sent to area where Iran-backed rebels attacked Saudi-led coalition ship': http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/10/03/us-warships-sent-to-area-where-iran-backed-rebels-attacked-saudi-led-coalition-ship.html
Clips from Fox article:
"Military officials sent the Navy warships to the southern end of the Bab al-Mandab Strait, also known as the Mandab Strait, which connects the Red Sea to the Gulf of Aden. Two U.S. Navy guided-missile destroyers, USS Mason and USS Nitze, armed with Tomahawk cruise missiles, Harpoon anti-ship missiles and an assortment of deck-mounted high-caliber machine guns, joined USS Ponce, a floating staging ship which includes a compliment of special operations forces, according to one official.
Describing the U.S. response to the Houthis and their Iranian backers, one official said, “This is a show of force,” adding, “It’s concerning anytime this happens.” Comments: US forces in area puts wild card in play, but generally agree with @fridhkleberg October 2 post and comments. Upvote 1. Adjusting down 5 basis points.

Raising 1 percent as the Kashmir flareup between India & Pakistan serves as a reminder that things still happen despite it not being in anyone's best interest. It's tempting to say that such things could lead to full blown military conflict, but look at Russia's relatively unimpeded aggression over the past few years, or Turkey's downing of  the Russian jet in the Syrian conflict. Some actors are toeing the line, asserting their claims of influence or control over territory and at times engaging in military campaigns or one-off military incidences designed to send a message regardless of justification. I think I've been at 1 percent merely leaving room for an accident, but I think I've ignored the willingness of some actors to "send a message" occasionally at the expense of lives whether the taking of said lives was intentional or not. Raising 1 percent is also a conscious effort and exercise in honing my calibration. I may be back down to 1 relatively soon and perhaps this move will hurt me relative to the median in the finally tally for this question, but this move is more about long-term gains in calibration...or so I hope.

We're talking about a 2-week period when this forecast is made, where a direct confrontation is hardly something in either Iran or anyone other countrie's interest at this time. Conflicts currently playing out via proxies. It's not technically impossible however unlikely, if something would spin of from Yemen (see recent reporting on Houthi encounted with UAE force http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/10/yemen-houthis-claim-attack-uae-military-vessel-161001212236896.html), but the time frame is just too small. 8% yes is in my opinion erring on the high side of probability but I will leave it there.

Author Fleitz, (2016) states that: On Monday, International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) director general Yukiya Amano explained what had up to this point been a mystery: namely, why its recent reports on Iran’s nuclear program have been so vague and contain such little data. As it turns out, under the Iran nuclear deal or Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), there are now limitations on what the IAEA is allowed to report. According to Amano, due to new U.N. Security Council and IAEA resolutions, the agency will only monitor and verify Iran’s compliance with its JCPOA commitments and will no longer provide broad reporting on its nuclear program. A December 15, 2015, IAEA Board of Governors resolution directed the organization to cease reporting on Iran’s compliance with its Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty obligations and past Security Council resolutions because the Board of Governors is no longer seized of this matter (para 1). Fleitz, F. (2016). In Yet Another Secret Side Deal, Iran’s Nuclear Violations Won’t Be Publicly Disclosed. National Review. Retrieved from
http://www.nationalreview.com/article/432516/iran-nuclear-deal-iaea-reports-violations-disclosure
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Author Landay (2016) states that: WASHINGTON The United States and its negotiating partners agreed "in secret" to allow Iran to evade some restrictions in last year's landmark nuclear agreement in order to meet the deadline for it to start getting relief from economic sanctions, according to a think tank report published on Thursday.
The report, which was released by the Washington-based Institute for Science and International Security, is based on information provided by several officials of governments involved in the negotiations. The group's president David Albright, a former U.N. weapons inspector and co-author of the report, declined to identify the officials, and Reuters could not independently verify the report's assertions (¶ 1-2).  Landay, J. (2016). U.S., others agreed 'secret' exemptions for Iran after nuclear deal: think tank. Reuters. World. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-exemptions-exclusive-idUSKCN1173LA

The Iranians made three radio calls to the two planes warning them not to enter Iranian airspace and risk being shot down with surface-to-air missiles, the official said. 
"All three calls used threatening language," the US defense official said.
The US Navy crews knew they were flying "outside the known range of Iranian air defenses" and proceeded with their flight plans (¶ 1-4). Starr, B. (2016). US official: Navy aircraft threatened with shoot down by Iran. CNN. Retrieved from

Author Martinez (2016) states that: Iranian fast boats have once again harassed an American ship in the Persian Gulf, forcing a U.S. Navy patrol boat to take evasive maneuvers to avoid a collision with one of the Iranian boats. 
American officials have labeled the Iranian actions in Sunday's encounter involving the USS Firebolt as "unsafe and unprofessional." It is the latest in a string of such incidents over the past two weeks in which small craft from the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Navy (IRGCN) have harassed U.S. Navy ships in the Gulf. 
"The USS Firebolt, a patrol craft, was operating in international waters in the central Arabian Gulf, was approached by seven fast-attack craft from Iran," Capt. Jeff Davis, a Pentagon spokesman, told reporters today. (¶ 1-3). Martinez, L. (2016). 7 Iranian Boats Harass Navy Ship in Gulf. Good Morning America. Retrieved from
https://www.yahoo.com/gma/7-iranian-boats-harass-navy-ship-gulf-183806915--abc-news-topstories.html

Disturbing propaganda video.
http://www.bizpacreview.com/2016/09/04/allah-obliterates-us-navy-fleet-iran-spits-face-new-music-video-386764 I am not a supporter of Iran, but I am a supporter of good understanding. We cannot allow ourselves to be satisfied with knowledge of only the "what" in this instance (that Iran has a definite hostile attitude). Our inquiry is not complete, and therefore unsatisfactory to good understanding, if we do not inquire deeply into the "why" aspect. Why is it (what are the *reasons*) that Iran holds such antagonistic beliefs against the United States? Such an understanding would not diminish our legitimate concerns as to the "what" (this is dangerous stuff), but would inform us as to what our true interests are and what we might do about them. Moderate the visceral reaction and let's find out what's really going on here.

Axe (2016) states that: Four times last week, speedboats belonging to Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps – a sort of government-sanctioned Islamic militia – harassed four American vessels patrolling the Persian Gulf.
The incidents, while tense, ended bloodlessly. Still, they offered a glimpse into the kinds of methods Tehran could employ to potentially devastating effect during a shooting war.
Outgunned by the United States' much larger and more sophisticated weaponry, Iran's troops have, for decades, honed so-called "swarm tactics" that could reduce America's technological advantage.
Instead of trying to match the U.S. military weapon-for-weapon, Iran deploys large numbers of relatively unsophisticated systems on land, at sea and in the air. The idea is to overwhelm American forces, much in the way a single bee is a nuisance to a human being but a swarm of them could prove lethal (para. 1-3). Axe, D. (2016). Commentary: Here’s how the U.S. Navy will defeat Iran’s speedboats. Reuters. Commentary. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-navy-iran-commentary-idUSKCN1151SB

Fewer than five U.S. service people are now assigned full-time to the "Joint Combined Planning Cell," which was established last year to coordinate U.S. support, including air-to-air refueling of coalition jets and limited intelligence-sharing, Lieutenant Ian McConnaughey, a U.S. Navy spokesman in Bahrain, told Reuters.
That is down from a peak of about 45 staff members who were dedicated to the effort full-time in Riyadh and elsewhere, he said."   Comments: Less eyes in the region concerns me.  Adjusting up 5 basis points on latest incident.

Between now and Oct 18 is 2 months = 1/6 of a year. So Final number is .5/6%. This is roughly 0.1%.

The Geopolitics of the Strait of Hormuz and the Iran-Oman Relations
Author Hafeznia, (2012) states that: From a geographic point of view, a strait is a narrow channel that joins two larger adjacent bodies of water in a natural way. The Strait of Hormuz is a maritime channel that joins the Persian Gulf to the Sea of Oman. Iran is located on the north shores of the Strait, and Oman on its south shores. Straits can separate two adjacent landmasses, as the Strait of Dover, which separate France. In that case, the separation is political rather than geographical. Straits can connect adjacent landmasses as well. Although the Strait of Hormuz separates Iran and Oman, it is at the same time a channel connecting them to each other. Tis has had a major impact on their relationship.
So far, the Strait of Hormuz and its various, important aspects have been the subject of many books and papers. Ali Asghar Kazemi considers the legal regime of the Strait of Hormuz in his book entitled, The Legal Aspects of Iran’s Sovereignty in the Persian Gulf the book entitled, the Persian Gulf and the Strategic Role of the Strait of Hormuz written by M. R. Hafeznia, discusses the natural, political, strategic and geopolitical aspects of the Strait of Hormuz. Homayoun Elahi allocates a chapter of his book, the Persian Gulf and its Problems, to the geographical and legal particularities of the Straits. The book entitled the Persian Gulf and the Indian Ocean in International Politics, written by Abbas Amiri, contains chapters on the policies of major and regional powers towards the Persian Gulf and the importance of the oil in the region for the world economy (Amiri, 1975). Ruhollah Ramazani, too, in his book, the Persian Gulf and the Strait of Hormuz, discusses the role of the Strait in the world economy, the policies of the United States and Russia towards the Persian Gulf and the Strait’s crises (1979) (¶ 1-2). Hafeznia, M., R. (2012). The Geopolitics of the Strait of Hormuz and the Iran-Oman Relations. Iranian Review of Foreign Affairs. 2 (4), 7-40. Retrieved from
https://www.ciaonet.org/attachments/20426/uploads.

Saudi Arabia Strikes Back
Hannah, J. (2016). Saudi Arabia Strikes Back. Foreign Policy Magazine. Retrieved from
https://www.yahoo.com/news/saudi-arabia-strikes-back-212350363.html For those concerned about the fallout from President Barack Obama and his administration’s nuclear deal with Iran — the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, or JCPOA — the hits just keep on coming. The recent revelation that the United States handed over $400 million in cash to Iran on the same day that it was releasing four American captives is but the latest disturbing detail in the saga that has become Obama’s extended experiment in appeasing the mullahs. Add it to the long list of other threatening post-deal developments, including the intensification of Iran’s ballistic missile program, the continuation of its efforts to illicitly procure nuclear materials, and the expansion of its aggressive and destabilizing activities across the Middle East. Oh, and don’t forget the detention of three new American hostages, of course.

Shipping access is one of the Iranians "big cards." For a "big card" to have value it must be understood to be playable by ones opponent. I expect the recent intensified pace of escalated cards being played, or threatened to be played, in anticipation of the fall of Mosul and the internal political-economic arrangement within Iraq (not least of all future access the oil reserves nearby Mosul and Kirkuk), to continue. Thus, whether Iran will be called upon to demonstrate their willingness to play this card (on an initial small, demonstratory scale) will be contingent upon the actual direction of the resolution of the Iraqi issues. At the moment, the Iraqi government appears to be committed in a direction that would (from how little I really know) seem to be satisfactory to Iran, so my initial forecast will be low. I would not expect Iran to obtain its objectives uncontested however, so my estimate is not too low. I would suspect that Iran will, if necessary, indeed play this card fully if they determine it to be necessary, with or without a preliminary demonstration. A creative aside: Ever since Politico published that story about a retired U.S. general suggesting that Obama may be "pushing" the Mosul offensive, and found other "senior military officials" to put an actual October start date on the offensive, they and others are promoting the notion of the re-taking of Mosul as being a possible "October Surprise" type of event. I think such an analogy is a bit of a stretch because, in my opinion, the vast majority of Americans (90%?) have no idea where Mosul is, what it's relevance is to anything in their lives is, and honestly, couldn't care one way or the other. Not sufficient in itself to "defeat ISIS," the media, no matter how hard they tried, couldn't push that lead balloon anywhere near to where it would make one iota of difference in the election. What WOULD make a difference, however, is some "unexpected" engagement of the U.S. fleet.

Armed Forces General Staff (AFGS) Chief IRGC Maj. Gen. Mohammad Bagheri discussed his priorities on the sidelines of his swearing-in ceremony. Bagheri told reporters that “increasing the defensive power and improving the capabilities of the armed forces and upgrading the Basij” are among his most important goals as AFGS chief. He also noted that his priorities include “promoting the readiness and the defense of the Islamic Republic’s national interests beyond its borders, like in the Persian Gulf, the Strait of Hormuz, the Gulf of Oman, and the northern Indian Ocean. Given these priorities, we can expect Iran to counter any potential threats in the Gulf as it places it military readiness as the highest priority. Conflict with civilians would seem somewhat more complicated in its monitoring.   We can therefore expect limited, if any confrontation in the Persian Gulf.
